msItem.note: A later erased note: Precepta rei rustice.

msItem.title: Two Macrobian zone-maps of the earth

msItem.note: The first showing the five habitable and uninhabitable zones, the 4th of which contains the Antipodes qui sub terra sunt et pedes habent contra nos versos

The second is lettered like the diagram which illustrates Macrobius, De somno Scipionis, 11. v. 13, but its descriptive text is derived as well from II. vii. 4; ed. Eyssenhardt, Leipzig, 1893, pp. 601, 608 and diags. iv-v.
Lists of names, some glossed, of the Fates, Furies, Harpies, Graces, and Gorgons.

msItem.title: De minutiis
msItem.note: Ed. N. Bubnov, Gerberti Opera Mathematica, Berlin, 1899, in App. 1B, iv, pp. 228–44.
A table, pr. Bubnov, pp. 227–8. The table differs considerably from the printed edition. In the MSS. cited by Bubnov this table is only found at the beginning in Munich clm. 14272.
Bubnov, p. 228 n. 4, only found this piece in Munich clm. 14272 and 14689 and Oxford, St. John’s College MS. 17. It is also found in MS. D’Orville 158, 11th cent., fol. 122v.
Following the text is a short passage, added in a different hand:
msItem.incipit: Et secundum superiorem regulam sicut precepimus caute dividatur. Quotlibet asses precesserint
msItem.explicit: assium in se qui minucias precedunt.
msItem.note: The section beg.: Quotlibet is part of an alien fragment following the treatise found in several MSS., including Munich clm. 14689 and pr. A. Olleris, Œuvres de Gerbert, Paris, 1867, p. 345; see Bubnov, p. 244 n. There is an addition in the same hand on fol. 2, marked for insertion by d in text and h in margin: De Sescuntia beg.: Sescuntia in sextantem fit sicilicus, which is not in Bubnov (p. 230 l.26).

msItem.incipit: Sole lucente quęcumque res illa fuerit sub divo
Est et alia ratio altitudinem videndi quę est huiusmodi. Hortogonium cuius katetus.
msItem.note: Bk. iii. 9 and iv. 48 of Geometria incerti auctoris ed. Bubnov, op. cit., pp. 323, 358. The same fragments are found in Munich clm. 14689.

msItem.author: Regino of Prüm
msItem.title: Epistola de harmonica institutione
msItem.incipit: Nosse oportet peritum cantorem quod non omnis tonorum
msItem.note: § 2. PL 132 col. 485B3–486A7. The version in our MS. is slightly shortened.

msItem.title: A short treatise on the monochord
msItem.incipit: Monochordum divisurus. Tres primum magodas providendum censeo, quę fiant hoc modo
msItem.note: Also found in MS. D’Orville 158 cit., fol. 120, and in Munich clm. 19489, 11th cent., Tegernsee, p. 62, and 23577, 11th cent., fol. 75.

msItem.title: A diagram of contingent propositions
msItem.incipit: Primus ordo consequentię. Possibile est esse
msItem.note: Derived from the table in Boethius, Comm. on Aristotle De Interpretatione, Ed. Prima, Bk. II, c. 13, ed. Meiser, Leipzig, 1877, p. 180.

msItem.author: Hucbald of St-Amand
msItem.title: Ecloga de caluis
msItem.rubric: Egloga de Calvis in qua habetur Paronomeon versuum cxxxiii
msItem.note: Ed. P. von Winterfeld in M.G.H. Poetarum Lat. Med. Aev. iv, i, 1899, pp. 267–71. He used our MS., which was then at Maihingen; it belongs to the non-interpolated group. On fol. 7v a slightly later hand has added the heading: Egloga de calvis in qua habetur Parameon versuum cxxxvi. Egloga Hugbaldi de calvis cuius hęc est causa carminis.
A blank space of half a column remains on fol. 8v.

msItem.author: Palladius
msItem.title: De re rustica
msItem.note: Ed. Schmitt, Leipzig, 1898. Each book is preceded by a list of chapters. Bk. II beg. fol. 20v; Bk. III, fol. 24v. Ends (fol. 31rb 1. 7) in the middle of a sentence in hi. 24 (Schmitt p. 97 1. 26): adlevandus est sarculo. The rest of fol. 31rb is left blank. Only fol. 9–10v are rubricated.

supportDesc.collation: 1⁸ (4 and 5 are singletons), 2⁸–3⁸, 4⁸ (3 and 6 are singletons) minutionem

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled space 210 145–55 : 33 lines, fol. 1–7 in long lines; ruled with a hard point

handDesc.handNote: Written in several hands in Germany in the 11th cent.

binding.p: Modern binding of dark-brown morocco by Maltby of Oxford.

history.provenance: Identifiable as L.47 in the catalogue of Tegernsee made by Konrad Sortorius, librarian 1500–1531 (Krämer, op. cit., 85). Krämer, B.L.R. IX, 4 (1976), 199–207 and plate XII (fol. 7v). A 15th-cent. hand has added marginal descriptions of pieces throughout the MS (identifiable as Ambrosius Schwarzenbeck, librarian of Tegernsee 1481–1500; see S. Krämer in Codices manuscripti I, 3 (1975), 84–5).
Formerly MS.1.2.fol.5 in the Fürstliche Oettingen-Wallerstein’sehe Bibliothek, Maihingen; library stamp on pastedown. See Neues Archiv vii, 180; vol. cit., p. 261.
No. 10 in Catalogue xix (1936) of L’Art Ancien S.A., Zurich.
Bought by Lyell in February 1942 from A. Rosenthal; see his Cat. i (1939), no. 19 and pl. iv (fol. 7v).
history.acquisition: Chosen as one of the hundred manuscripts bequeathed to the Bodleian by Lyell in 1948.
